_header: Whoso beholdeth well as with my eye
Note:
Translated from his French poem printed in Champollion-Figeac (1842)
XChampollion-Figeac, Aime. Les Poesies du duc Charles d’Orleans. Paris, 1842, 30.
_description: Charles d’Orléans, a roundel — fourteen lines

BodHerD38.Editions:
Hausknecht,  Emil. 
             “Vier gedichte von Charles d’Orleans.” 
             Anglia
         17 (1895): 445-7: 477.
Bliss,  Philip. 
             Reliquiae Hearnianae.
         London: J. Russel Smith, 1869: 1.266-7.

BLHar682.First Lines:
Who so biholdith wel as with my eyeMi verry lady and my sul
                    maystres…
BLHar682.Last Lines:
…In hir he shalle se a gret and hvug largesOf plesaunce
                    spryngyng from gret to more goodly
BLHar682.Note: As written, repeats first words of lines 1-2 at end to indicate going back to first four lines of the roundel.
